184503640.review:
A sad 9/10.
For a free game with a tiny, TINY, TIIIINY playerbase, Istrolid is pretty good.
The single player is so engaging that I wish the developers had pivoted to making a full on campaign and charging money for it.

As it stands, Istrolid is an RTS game where you, the player, make the units that you(or an Ai that you spend a few minutes creating) will pilot.

There's a lot to manage, a lot of creativity put into this very simple cute little indie title.

If there's any problems I have with Istrolid, it just comes from the fact that the devs have more or less moved on from development of the game. That's perfectly fine, I get it. Life moves on, but I do hope that one day they will come back and/or drop some new game with similar gameplay to istrolid because no other RTS i've ever played has had the level of creativity that Istrolid brings to the table.

Ships built in istrolid are more or less balanced around a "Rock paper scissors lizard spock Doc-ock" kind of format, where Ship type X beats Ship type S and Z but loses to Y, R, and H.

Makes for an interesting dynamic, especially since with player skill the weaknesses of certain fleets of ships can be overcome, such as ships that run out of energy quickly, they could be followed by a ship that *JUST* keeps those ships powered up, but if the ships that work as batteries get blown up by an enemy Kamakaze nuke then those running bombers can quickly become useless, so it's reasonable to make smaller ships to purposely get the kamikaze to blow up prematurely, then the other player can use the Nuke as a "threat" to keep the other player on-guard and keep their eyes and attention away from other points of interest.

ETC, ETC. 

There is so much depth in this game, locked behind a dwindling playerbase and increasingly smaller dev teams(if any are left). 

Even with all that, Istrolid's single player is still worth playing through as a 9/10 experience.
